NCDC’s maps for temperature anomalies continue to show that Greenland is being hard hit by higher temperatures. This, too, can be a narrative in its own way and it’s very visual:

http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov...

Again, no loaded words, and no inflammatory language. Just red and blue dots on a map. A child could easily see that the red dots far outnumber the blue dots.

The red dots appear to be winning.

NASA Facts, April 1998, NF-222

Global records of surface temperature over the last 100 years show a rise in global temperatures (about 0.5° C overall), but the rise is marked by periods when the temperature has dropped as well. If the models cannot explain these marked variations from the trend, then we cannot be completely certain that we can believe in their predictions of changes to come. For example, in
the early 1970’s, because temperatures had been decreasing for about 25 to 30 years, people began predicting the approach of an ice age! For the last 15 to 20 years, we have been seeing a fairly steady rise in temperatures, giving some assurance that we are now in a global warming phase.

…

Can we match the observation of temperature trends with the model predictions? The temperature record of the past hundred years does show a warming trend, by approximately 0.5°C. However, the observed warming trend is not entirely consistent with the carbon dioxide change. Most of the temperature increase occurred before 1940, after which Earth started to cool until the early seventies, when warming resumed. Carbon dioxide, on the other hand, has been increasing steadily throughout the past century.

Dear NASA, what changed now?

In 1957 the Soviet Union hurled Sputnik into earth orbit and it was obvious that the US had fallen behind in engineering and technology. The shock galvanized the nation into action and soon funding issued forth for both basic and applied research and for the training of young scientists and engineers all across the sciences and technology. I was one of them -- I could not have attended graduate school without that financial support. What followed was many years of federal funding that saw enormous strides made in science and engineering that largely have shaped our world as we know it today.

Those days are long gone now, and science and engineering struggle to maintain momentum needed to fuel the fires of technology transfer and innovation for economic growth and to attract the best and the brightest to research careers. This is tragic, since it signals our surrender of leadership to others. More and more, the US is becoming a follower, rather than being the leader, and this will inevitably be reflected in the continuing weakness of our economy. Scientific and engineering research -- and strong and vibrant communities of researchers (the human resources) -- are national investments in our future. But alas, this deterioration should not be surprising in our country, where scientific illiteracy is shockingly high despite the need for a scientifically literate population to make wise public policy and manage scientific and technological resources. In a sense, the inmates are running the asylum.

Investing in our future is something that the political powers that be cannot seem to take seriously, whatever their stripe. I fear that it will take another Sputnik-like event to shake us loose from this complacency. But this time there is much more competition across the globe, and others are already racing ahead of us. If and when it comes, will we be up to the challenge?

Re: Mr. Roberts is seeking a new name for people seeking to avoid disruptive climate change and advance clean energy .

First, he might want to define "clean energy", since that term is being used by about every energy company, startup and wannabe. Looking at it as an engineer inside the energy industry, my reaction is that the term is much more about wish fulfillment than reality. It is like the search for perpetual motion. All energy sources have their good and bad points. Nothing is truly zero impact if you follow the process from the raw materials to final disposal. The trick is to balance the negative impact with the positive outcomes. (Of course, there are wide differences among individuals and societies when we are weighing the negative versus the positive).

So, if nothing else, I'd start by saying "cleanER energy" to remove any mindset of utopia. That still leaves the problem that the term can encompass solar, geothermal, nuclear, hydroelectric, sequestered coal and steriod-enhanced pandas on treadmills, but it’s a start. As to what to call the people working on all this stuff, get some clever comedy writers focused on that. Or just go with Energy Questers, and be done with it.

James Aach - author of Rad Decision, the insider novel of nuclear power.

The long slow decline in respect for science and technology over the past 30? no 40 years is in part due to over promising, and lots of high profile environmental and economic disasters that appear to be caused by technology. There have been medical "breakthroughs" that don't pan out, chemical disasters like Bhopal or Love Canal, or the recent fracas over bph. It was great to get to the moon, but then what?

I suspect things like going to the moon, winning WWII or winning the cold war, with a clear, finite and reachable goal can get people fired up, but when we reach the goal it's hard to keep up that enthusiasm.

I would love to see more public support for basic science. Popular support is a prerequisite to getting decent political support, and of course, getting funding.
